Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Qalaxia: skill-aware query engine for K12 Classrooms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project builds a new query engine for K12 that addresses four major shortcomings in existing automated question-answering systems. The shortcomings prevent both students and teachers from fully leveraging the power of such systems. Existing systems 1) cannot handle raw student queries like - Ten Ford Fiestas cost $146,000. How much does each Ford Fiesta cost?, 2) do not take into account students' skill-levels to return results that is within the scope of their understanding, 3) do not have a community vetting and feedback mechanism that allows systems to learn the quality of their automated answers, and 4) discard valuable insights obtainable from students' queries that can be used to inform future classroom instruction. The query engine, which is free to use, addresses all four shortcomings, improves classroom instruction and closes the achievement gap. It empowers students of all abilities and from all communities to obtain automated answers from the AI technology and regular answers from the community of users. The community of users on the platform range from students to teachers to experts from the industry fulfilling their corporate social responsibilities. The platform is compliant with federal and state privacy regulations and is projected to earn significant Annual Recurring Revenue from corporations and EdTech companies seeking to build their brand among the K12 community.


This project develops new skill-aware AI technology that automatically maps student's raw queries into topics, sub-topics and intent. The technology considers the user skill-levels and automatically constructs an answer extracted from the most relevant educational resources, with highest preference given to teachers' own resources. The technology does something more if the detected topic falls under Algebra and the intent of the query is 'How do I solve this?' It generates, on-the-fly, additional scaffolding instructions for solving the problem. This approach extends to disciplines beyond Algebra. In addition, Phase I research leverages the latest advancements in Machine Learning, Natural Language Processing and Topic Detection to extract and track skill-levels, as well as strengths and weaknesses of students for teacher's benefit. Finally, the project will also demonstrate the efficacy of the technology in terms of queries made, relevant responses generated and its impact in terms of Algebra math outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has made new technical advancements in the field of natural language processing, specifically in the field of semantic classification and information retrieval. 

 

The impact of the technology developed in the project is in helping create equity of access to expertise. Current search engines do not provide relevant answers to student queries. E.g. A query of the form "100 Ford trucks cost a $1.46 million, how much does each truck cost?" provides links to auto dealerships as its search results. Poor answers and poor results to students' search queries creates inequity of access to expertise as students from underrepresented communities do not have access to experts at home who are able to provide relevant answers to their queries. Furthermore, teachers do not have any visibility into their students' questions robbing them of an opportunity to understand their students' needs, thus compounding the inequity.

 

Therefore, the technology developed in this project creates a broader societal impact by 1) helping students receive better answers to their questions and better results to their search queries and 2) providing teachers with insights into their students? need and helps teachers reassess their lesson plans. 

 

Proof of concept of Qalaxia's utility was demonstrated in a 9thgrade Algebra classroom of 129 students over Winter semester 2020.

 

Specifically, the outcomes of the project are as follows:

*    A fully functional query engine that has been productized and deployed. Here is the demo of how Qalaxia can provide better results than Google - https://youtu.be/MGV9BGkuk4A

*    Extracting answers from teachers? own resources in their Google drive - https://youtu.be/c8qFPI_9Z1k

*     A fast semantic question classifier algorithm that immediately uses newly labeled data to classify new data ? demo at https://youtu.be/tGQSs5kkL4

*     New binary word embeddings and dimension preserving compositions to generate phrase, sentence and paragraph embeddings that preserve the visibility of individual words in the overall sentence embedding ? demo of its performance at https://youtu.be/zokPI8YbRxE, demo of its productization into Qalaxia at https://youtu.be/S14nQyWdHNg

*     Integrating with Google Sheets ? demo at https://youtu.be/3Paaj7_fHfk

*     Novel discrete positive-valued word, phrase, and sentence embeddings; and corresponding new hierarchical clustering algorithms and their implementation in python for fast classification and semantic search

*     Demonstration of Qalaxia?s utility in an Algebra classroom of 129 students in improving math outcomes and confidence in math abilities

*     Teacher's report showing a summary of searches performed and questions asked by students ? demo at https://youtu.be/RKmQ-kE_cVY

*      Over the past 18 months Qalaxia has gained additional 1300 registered users, bringing out registered user count to approximately 3100 and our Monthly Active User count has crossed 5000. Qalaxia receives visitors from across the world and from all the continents (except Antarctica). Majority of the visitors are from the US and India.

*      Creation of training data repositories required for providing automated answers to student questions

         *    Skills Database

         *    Duplicate-question database

         *    Question-Answer Database
